explanation: "The relevant information about the claim is lacking in the context."
Matthew Gray Gubler is an actor.
Saw II sold over 3 million units, however it does not say whether it sold them on DVD.
The claim is that Matthew Gray Gubler is not an actor. The evidence says that he is an American actor. So, the claim is false.

The claim is that Saw II sold over 3 million units. The evidence says that Saw II was released to DVD and topped charts its first week, selling more than 3 million units. So we can infer that the claim is true.

The first sentence is the claim and the second sentence is the evidence. The evidence is saying "It is available as a generic medication and is sold under many trade names worldwide." The word "and" is joining two ideas together, so we can split the evidence into two parts. Part A is "It is available as a generic medication." Part B is "It is sold under many trade names worldwide." We can see that Part A is true because the medication is available as a generic. Part B is also true because it is sold under many trade names worldwide. Therefore, the entire claim is true.
